title: Flagstaff Lake (Oregon)
text:
Flagstaff Lake is one of a group of interconnected, <a href="alkali">alkali</a>ne, high-desert lakes known as the "<a href="Warner%20Lakes">Warner Lakes</a>" in the <a href="Warner%20Valley">Warner Valley</a> of <a href="Lake%20County%2C%20Oregon">Lake County</a> in the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Oregon">Oregon</a>. Flagstaff Lake lies between Upper Campbell Lake to the north and Swamp Lake to the south, about northeast of <a href="Lakeview%2C%20Oregon">Lakeview</a>. It has a surface area of about and a shoreline of about .
The Warner Lakes vary in depth and volume depending on the weather and have completely dried up at times. Fish populations also vary. During a drought from 1988 to 1992, when all of the lakes went dry, some fish survived by retreating into a <a href="slough%20%28hydrology%29">slough</a> connected to the lakes. Historically, fish species in the lakes have included <a href="crappie">crappie</a>, <a href="brown%20bullhead">brown bullhead</a>, <a href="largemouth%20bass">largemouth bass</a>, and <a href="redband%20trout">redband trout</a>.
